title: Monday, 13th November, 2017

Think we've gone below the 200 day MA for cable, in case anyone imagines that to be significant.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

...... thing is, why was the weekend bad for sterling?

BE11:12am

Theresa's looking a bit more embattled, but "more" is a relative term here.

PM11:12am

Perhaps shambles compounds, like interest

11:13 am
BE11:13am

Sure, but I just don't quite understand what endgame we're playing out in the model here. Are we now betting on harder Brexit? Or another snap election? Or a Johnson-Gove annexing of Downing Street? Or no deal? Or .....

BE11:13am

Have some Citi, to fill the space.

BE11:14am

Prime Minister Theresa May is under growing pressure from abroad, Parliament and within her own party as deadlines juxtapose. At the concluding press conference of the sixth round of UK/EU negotiations last Friday, EU Commission Chief Negotiator Michel Barnier confirmed that the EU expects the UK to provide detail on its intentions regarding the financial settlement, citizenship rights and the Irish border within two weeks (i.e. by 24 November) in order to prepare the 14/15 December EU summit. In response, UK Brexit Secretary David Davis told Sky News that “in every negotiation, each side tries to control the timetable. The real deadline on this is, of course, December”. He added that the UK would take its time and that the EU is not expecting a sum or a formula that would allow calculating a sum. At home, the Daily Mail reported that leading anti-EU ministers Boris Johnson and Michael Gove had sent a “secret letter” to the Prime Minister urging that any transition must end in June 2021 and criticizing that some ministers had not “internalized” the logic of Brexit. Meanwhile, the Sunday Times reports that 40 Conservative MPs are now ready to write letters to their party’s 1922 Committee indicating they have no confidence in the Prime Minister. If the number grows to 48, a confidence vote would be triggered – and thus a
leadership contest could be triggered. The Independent reports that the Committee Stage of the EU Withdrawal Bill, which begins this week on 14 and 15 November, will go on into December, as the remaining six days of debate will only be scheduled after the Budget, in order to gain time for the government to convince potential rebels. Comment: Much of the domestic and international news is probably just noise, but the further delay in the EU Withdrawal Bill suggests that the government sees a real risk to its majority. The EU’s deadline on 24 November falls right in the middle of the UK’s budget deliberations and the EU Withdrawal Bill, which means MPs could see them as proxies for the government’s Brexit negotiation strategy. In this situation, the government may not be able to make the concessions necessary to get “sufficient progress” progress towards trade and transition talks at the 14/15 December EU summit.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

And Natixis ....

BE11:16am

Sterling firmed slightly, the GBP/USD stabilising around 1.315, before correcting this Monday morning towards 1.3090, in reaction to the confusion at local political level (two cabinet ministers resigned this past week, with another two mired in controversy). Theresa May outlined plans to set the UK’s EU departure date, namely 29 March 2019. For Labour, this leaving date does not give enough time to finalise what are arduous negotiations. It would seem that the Prime Minister’s position regarding the Brexit bill (€20bn proposed by the UK, €60bn-€100bn demanded by the EU) could be mollified.

BE11:17am

Once this issue has been resolved, negotiations can open over the transition period and future trade relations. The issue of the Irish border is also likely to be a pressing matter. Watch out for the next batch of figures concerning inflation (which could impact expectations of a hike in the bank rate, despite the Bank of England being rather dovish), retail sales and unemployment, which could shed more light on the state of the British economy. In this context, sterling can be expected to continue to chart a rather jagged course, with the GBP/USD fluctuating between 1.305 and 1.325, but only if the economy proves resilient and inflation remains firm. If not, a breakout below the support at 1.305 cannot be ruled out.

11:17 am
PM11:18am

thanks for that

undefined
PM11:18am

Oh no! Look what's landed

11:18 am
PM11:18am

Outlook 2018

BE11:18am

/o\

PM11:18am

We're not even half way through November

11:18 am
PM11:19am

Nick Nelson, Head of European Equity Strategy -- UBS

BE11:19am

Always a gamble to see whether John Lewis ad comes before the first year-forward preview. This year, only just.

BE11:19am

Go on, what does he say?

11:19 am
PM11:19am

Just one blob

PM11:19am

2018: Year 2 of a new Profit Cycle…
We see a new profit cycle driven by: (1) the return of the top-line, (2) operating leverage, (3) re-gearing balance sheets and, (4) the return of capex. We think there is a risk that investors see 2017 as a one-off base effect-driven recovery, but underlying data suggest something more: margins are rising at the fastest rate in 7yrs, trailing earnings are the highest in 6 years and Q3 results so far are better than Q2. For potential stocks that have been left behind in the RoE recovery please see LINK.

Target 440 Stoxx 600 end-2018: c. 13% upside
We recalibrate our top-down earnings model as it had been persistently underestimating the turn in operational leverage (Figure 1). We now see 10% EPS growth in 2018. Consensus estimates are 8.9%, but adjusting for the average upward bias, underlying "true" consensus may be as low as c.2%. We see modest P/E re-rating to 15.7x from 15.0x currently. For the FTSE 100, we are more conservative and target 7,900 end-2018 (c.6% upside).

Upside risks: re-rating, re-gearing, M&A. Downside risks: higher rates, volatility
Upside risks: equities re-rate to previous peak valuations (c.33%upside), corporates re-gear aggressively, US investors return, M&A picks up (currently c.30% below US run rates), effective labour market reform in France (a "free-option"). Downside risks: rates rise too fast (but some offsets – c.25% mkt cap is Financials), much stronger Euro (stay domestic), sharp rise in volatility / political risk (Spain, Italy).

Sector Changes – (some) leaders will be followers and (some) followers leaders
Key themes that we highlighted before, such as operating leverage, played a part in the sectors which lead the EPS momentum this year (e.g., Luxury Goods and Autos). In the case of the Luxury Goods sector, we now downgrade it to Neutral from Overweight as EPS momentum is fading and we do not expect this year's strong performance to continue into 2018 (Figure 2). And we upgrade Tobacco to Neutral from Underweight as we think the underperformance might have run its course now. The sector is offering attractive yields again and its performance looks too negative even relative to the current strong PMIs.

PM11:19am

Done.

We'll try and usual place a pack of them

PM11:20am

(@BornCynic: He's been sacked and there are criminal charges raised against him, last I checked. But haven't been following closely.)

Well, there's the Ultra warning.

11:20 am
Ultra Electronics Holdings PLC (ULE:LSE): Last: 1,243, down 284 (-18.60%), High: 1,302, Low: 1,155, Volume: 2.60m
BE11:21am

You'll remember Ultra came off pretty sharply on Friday, which seemed a severe reaction to a three month delay on an acquisition.

PM11:21am

hmm -- might well be a Stewards there

11:21 am
BE11:22am

Yep. Though there was also a pretty good Berenberg note going around that talked about how defence budgets were stretched, and the cheapish and short-order-visibility stuff Ultra makes would be an easy thing to cut.

BE11:22am

Turns out that was pretty prescient.

BE11:22am

Post market close we got a massive profit warning and the ousting of CEO Rakesh Sharma.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

And as Berenberg said, it's UK mostly.

BE11:23am

Though I don't have their note open right now, so here's JP Morgan to summarise.

BE11:24am

ULE began 2017 with consensus expecting 2-3% organic growth in 2017. At the half year, the guidance was lowered to 0-1%. ULE now expects -4%. The main culprit appears to be the UK defence market. Although this is only c10-15% of group sales (c£100m), ULE says that over £20m of contracts have been delayed deferred cancelled due to budgetary pressures. There is no guidance on 2018 but we have lowered our organic growth forecast to c1% from c3%, but it may be better/weaker than this.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

ULE now expects an EBITA margin of c15.6% in 2017, vs our expectation of 16.4%. In the absence of guidance, we assume that margins stay at 15.6% (pre Sparton acquisition).

BE11:25am

ULE will take exceptional charges for three items in 2017: (1) M&A fees which we agree are exceptional; (2) legal fees for the terminated Oman contract will be c£8m, above the £2.4m we assumed. We assume no further Oman charges after 2017; and (3) restructuring charges will be c£8.5mn, slightly lower than the £10m we expected.

BE11:25am

You'll remember that Ultra hasn't done organic growth since the Spice Girls were still together.

11:25 am
PM11:25am

(wayneJ -- that FT copyright msg drives us mad as well, as you might guess.)

BE11:25am

.... And yet another warning raises all sorts of concerns to that end.

PM11:25am

When did the Spice Girls split?

11:26 am
PM11:26am

2008, if you include the reunion

BE11:26am

I don't know. I was just using it as a shorthand for "a long time ago". I don't have a mark in my diary to mourn the date each year.

BE11:27am

Back to Caz.

11:26 am
BE11:27am

Bears have been concerned ULE would miss its 2017 target of 80% cash conversion (CC), and about ULE’s long-term contract accounting. ULE still expects to achieve 80% CC (excluding Oman from both EBITA and cash flow). ULE also confirmed that under IFRS 15 rules, its 2016 sales and EBITA would be broadly unchanged, which should help allay concerns on revenue recognition.

BE11:28am

What seems to be the thing underpinning shares right now is that the board is “minded to recommend” a final dividend of 35p

BE11:28am

So we still have a final of 50p.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Without that, I suspect we'd be into three figures by now.

BE11:29am

Quick bit of Goldman on what's next.

BE11:30am

We think investor attention will now turn to any change in strategy for the Group. In our view the key question is how to reinject growth into the group. The group has not registered positive organic revenue growth since 2011 and has averaged -4% since 2012. Overall revenues however have increased by 3% over the same period as the company has spent £356mn on acquisitions. Over the same period, spending on Capex + R&D has fallen from £68mn in 2012 to £35mn in 2016. The focus has therefore shifted from internal investment to external sources of growth and technology. If we were to include acquisition spend in the calculation of FCF (reflecting the focus on external sources of growth) then total FCF from 2012 to 2016 would have been -£47mn.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

So anyway, sector ..........

BAE Systems PLC (BA.:LSE): Last: 542.03, down 13.98 (-2.51%), High: 548.00, Low: 539.50, Volume: 3.97m
PM11:01am

Welcome to Markets Live

11:30 am

11:31 am

BE11:32am

PM11:32am

Still?

11:33 am
BE11:33am

Yep. As often happens when a company's having a strategic review. The noise level increases and the signal's often hard to pick out.

BE11:33am

So anyway, Sandy Morris of Jefferies reckons it might all be a bit overdone sector wise.

BE11:34am

And selling now "might, we think, risk 'buying the dummy' in the short term as the portents in the USA appear even more positive than we anticipated."

11:34 am
BE11:34am

(I think "buying the dummy" is a sports term? Like a headfake?)

BE11:34am

We believe it has been evident for some time that the overall
UK Defence Budget is under pressure, certainly that for the Royal Navy. The considerable costs associated with commissioning the UK's two Queen Elizabeth Class aircraft carriers have led to some near-term cash conservation and expendient cuts to expenditure being sought. Such a backdrop is likely familiar to a seasoned campaigner like BAE. While the UK represented 21% of BAE's sales in FY16, those sales were probably quite evenly balanced between platforms and services, in our view. Further, BAE's revenue from platforms is heavily supported by long-term contracts for Astute, Trident Successor and Type 26 Frigates. Getting the latter under contract last July was an important step in securing BAE's medium-term outlook, in our view.

BE11:35am

So, ignore Ultra's warning and concentrate on the recent order intake and then the path of the US FY18 NDAA.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

First, we recognise the difficulty of legislation passing Congress. Nonetheless, we remain optimistic that passage of the US FY18 Defense Budget will be achieved, probably now in 1Q18. The increased spending in the FY18 Budget would certainly create a more positive general backdrop for BAE and its peers, in our view. However, the Senate Armed Services Committee has proposed considerably greater funding still - a Base Budget of US632bn versus the Administration's requested US$603bn. Among the proposed increases is funding for the following: 94 rather than 70 F-35 JSF aircraft, 17 Lockheed MC-130J aircraft rather than 5, 24 F-18s rather than 14, and 13 P-8 Poseidon aircraft rather than 7. There is also considerably more proposed funding for new warships. Both equipment modernisation and shortfalls in readiness are intended to be addressed.

BE11:36am

.... which is a brave but reasonable argument.

undefined
11:36 am
BE11:36am

As noted on the right ........

BE11:36am

*GE PLANS TO CUT QUARTERLY DIVIDEND BY 50% TO 12C/SHR

BE11:37am

11:38 am

Okay, seems like the divi cut was anticipated.

PM11:38am

BE11:39am

11:39 am
BE11:39am

BE11:40am

Citi also ....

BE11:40am

GE’s financial reporting is overly complicated and, in
the view of many investors, not reflective of the underlying sustainable performance of the company. GE has previewed likely changes to how it will report results going forward that we think will drive greater comparability vs. peers and more closely align reported earnings with underlying cash generation. The good news is that “quality of earnings” should be perceived as higher over time; the bad news is that reported EPS could be materially lower on a go forward basis vs. GE’s current conventions (based on disclosures the company has made to date, we estimate a ~$0.30 headwind to our 2018 EPS estimate of $1.25). More transparency also means providing clarity on the dividend – we expect a 30%-50% cut – and the company’s go forward capital allocation framework.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

So, bottom of the expected range rather than out of the blue.

BE11:40am

And wouldn't read too much into the lack of share price move.

BE11:41am

Remember having to do breaking Wall Street corporate news while at Bloomberg, and having US editors shout about quoting the Frankfurt price when it hadn't traded for about a month.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

Fun times. Anyway, we'll come back to GE as and when required.

undefined
BE11:42am

Elsewhere in corporate ........ Ladbrokes?

11:42 am
PM11:42am

Ah yes

Ladbrokes Coral Group PLC (LCL:LSE): Last: 133.80, down 3.1 (-2.26%), High: 136.00, Low: 133.00, Volume: 3.43m
PM11:43am

Trading statement here https://www.invest...1711130700042482W/

11:43 am
BE11:43am

Still in a holding pattern ahead of the roulette machine review, which is now due some time next century I think.

PM11:43am

With luck

BE11:43am

Numbers are okay. Main concern is a bit of a slowdown of the online business.

11:43 am
BE11:44am

Which looks okay on the surface but it's all Coral rather than Ladbrokes.

BE11:44am

Now ........ This is slightly wandering subjects, and we will get to the actual figures, but bear with me here.................

PM11:45am

...

11:44 am
BE11:45am

A few weeks ago on here, I mentioned bonus bagging.

PM11:45am

ok

BE11:45am

There are lots of sites -- which you can Google yourself, I'm not linking to them -- that all do basically the same thing.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

They to sell you an alert for the available bookmaker promotions. Free bets, signup bonuses, rollovers, odds matching, etc.

BE11:46am

Often via livestreams or whatever. You match precisely what the person's doing and you take a relatively low risk return.

BE11:47am

Stuff like this has been running for nearly a decade. But it seems to have really gained traction in recent years. Search and you'll find lots of arguments on Mumsnet and HotUKDeals and stuff like that, as well as all the puff.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

Now .... I mention because I'm aware of people now doing this full time. As in, bonus bagging as their principal source of income.

PM11:48am

blimey

BE11:48am

One person I've spoken to has more than 30 bank accounts, so he can repeat bets across them all.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

And that person claims to be bringing in multiples of £k a month, tax free. THIS IS NOT A RECOMMENDATION OF THESE SCHEMES, TO BE CLEAR

BE11:49am

I note it mostly because something seems seriously wrong in the world of online gambling.

PM11:49am

I knew nothing about this. Fascinating

11:49 am
BE11:49am

When the amounts of cash they're prepared to give away is so much that people are building organised schemes to extract it efficiently.

BE11:50am

And, apparently, succeeding. We've noted in the past the extraordinary sums Plus500 pays to attract new customers .....

BE11:50am

.... I'd be interested to see similar figures for the non-financial betting industry, where regulation is rather more lax.

11:51 am
BE11:52am

Plus500's new user signup costs fell because the regulator came in and took out the weakest operators .... will that happen to sports gambling? Not sure. So how do you value the listed, scale operators in this incredibly expensive arms race? Not sure.

BE11:52am

Anyway, I note all this as a starting point rather than a conclusion. Back to Ladbrokes.

BE11:53am

Trading in line.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

Davy remains positive, pending the obvious.

BE11:53am

Ladbrokes Coral has reiterated guidance for 2017 (Davy forecast
EBIT: £313m) despite a slowdown in European sportsbook growth in the last ten weeks. Sportsbook net revenue growth, which had been up 29% in the first seven weeks of the half, has slowed to a run-rate of closer to 10%. That said, OTC staking trends and
gaming growth have both improved, while synergy delivery this year is also running £5-6m ahead of expectations. This means that our full year expectation is likely to be met. It may, however, mean that we reduce our 2018 forecast by circa 2.5%. Our overall view remains unchanged. We see good scope for the stock to perform well post regulatory review.

BE11:54am

Goodbody less so.

11:54 am
BE11:54am

From an operational perspective this is another solid update from Ladbrokes Coral. The trends remain broadly similar to those we have seen since the merger completed just over a year ago i.e good online growth offset by a lacklustre retail performance which faces numerous well flagged headwinds. The weakness in the Ladbrokes.com may be viewed negatively, but some of the issues here appear short term. We do not expect to make any material changes to our FY17 forecasts at this stage (EBITDA of £441m). The outcome of the triennial review and/or potential M&A are the key drivers of the investment case. We retain our HOLD recommendation.

Coca Cola HBC AG (CCH:LSE): Last: 2,460, down 125 (-4.84%), High: 2,535, Low: 2,422, Volume: 499.21k
12:02 pm
PM12:03pm

ok

BE12:03pm

Caz doing the damage.

BE12:03pm

We continue to believe CCH is on a strong fundamental growth trajectory and is best placed to acquire a stake in CCBA. However, the stock has increased by 70% (vs c20% increase in earnings estimates) since July 2016 vs. MSCI Europe FBT and FTSE100 flat/+12%. The market now appreciates CCH’s operational improvement as well as balance sheet optionality, in our view. We expect an announcement on CCBA in the next few months. However, we suspect accretion for CCH from a deal could be lower than previously anticipated given potential recent deterioration of profitability at CCBA. We would therefore take profit and await a better entry point post the CCBA announcement. On our estimates, CCH now trades on a CY18E PE of 21.1x vs the European Beverages sector on 21.9x and EV/EBITDA of 10.9x vs sector on 13.8x. We downgrade to Neutral (OW) with a 2,600p (2,800p) PT.

12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

Also, I think Coke -- as in the proper Coke, the US one -- has its first investor day in about a decade on Thursday.

BE12:04pm

Which might give a bit more detail on how the bottler-bottlee relationship will evolve.

BE12:04pm

Anyway, that's that.

12:04 pm
